author: By Gabby Sobelman and Euan Ward
title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Cross-Border Strikes
description: The strikes, in eastern Lebanon and the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, underscored how months of talks have failed to stop either the war in Gaza or the related conflict along the Lebanese border.
content: Israeli forces and Hezbollah militants in Lebanon traded cross-border strikes on Wednesday, fueling concerns about a wider regional conflagration as negotiators struggle to broker a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Gostin, Sam Halabi and Alexandra Finch
title: Another Pandemic Looms. Guess What? We’re Still Not Ready.
description: Africa has nowhere near the doses it needs to curb the outbreak.
content: Just one day after the World Health Organization declared the deadly mpox outbreak in Africa a global health emergency, Sweden reported its first case of a dangerous strain of the disease (and there may be more cases). The threat of a pandemic of mpox is here yet again. To curb this crisis, the affected countries in Africa need tests, vaccines and people to respond. Now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Democrats Use the Convention to Try to Define Trump as a Self-Interested Fraud
description: Speeches and videos seek to shrink Donald Trump in order to rise above him, as Kamala Harris and her allies work to minimize him and disengage from him.
content: How to attack former President Donald Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Bruenig
title: In a Union Triumph, the Seeds of Future Failure
description: The U.S. government’s arduous efforts to back the Starbucks campaign may be impossible to replicate.
content: Starting with one small shop in Buffalo, Starbucks workers have unionized 481 stores with more than 11,000 employees in less than three years. It’s a staggering demonstration of what can be accomplished when an aggressive union, an eager work force and a labor-friendly Democratic administration wind up in alignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Kushner
title: I Kept Failing to Learn French. This Is What Finally Worked.
description: Doing exercises in a book was très terrible. A friend suggested something more radical.
content: There’s a scene I love in the movie “Husbands,” when John Cassavetes, performing in his own film, is attempting to smooth-talk a beautiful blonde in a London casino. “What languages do you speak?” he asks her. None, she answers. “I’m going to give you a little bit of French,” he says, before launching, with seductive gravitas, into a language that sounds like French. But the words are nonsense. It’s fake French. “You like Italian?” he asks, and then he does his fake version. The woman laughs and says, “It’s not real.” “It’s real to me,” he replies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Isabel Kershner
title: PBS’s Woodruff Calls Comments Suggesting Trump and Netanyahu Discussed Cease-Fire a ‘Mistake’
description: Aides to the two men, who met last month at Mar-a-Lago, had denied that such a call had taken place.
content: The veteran PBS correspondent Judy Woodruff on Wednesday apologized for on-air comments suggesting there had been a phone call between former President Donald J. Trump and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to discuss a cease-fire deal. Aides to both men denied that such a call had taken place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Lynn Levy, Abdi Latif Dahir and Sonia Herrero
title: Beyoncé Loves Her Poetry. You Will, Too.
description: Warsan Shire's writing is fierce and urgent.
content: When Beyoncé released her album “Lemonade,” she gave many people their first glimpse into the world of the Somali British poet Warsan Shire — fragments of Shire’s poetry were woven throughout the album. But for Abdi Latif Dahir, East Africa correspondent for The New York Times, Shire’s work had already been close to his heart, and her poems have continued to inspire him for more than a decade. Dahir argues that now is the perfect time to read Warsan Shire’s work, and he explains why he considers her to be “our ultimate modern poet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: So You Want to Look Like a Streaming Star
description: Call the stylist Holly White, who has worked with breakout actors on “Bridgerton,” “House of the Dragon,” “The Crown” and more.
content: Streaming services can’t get enough of franchises: swaggering shows with sweeping locations, fertile plots and, perhaps most critically, large casts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Allen
title: Robert Louis Stevenson Loved Her. Many of His Friends Did Not.
description: In her engrossing book “A Wilder Shore,” Camille Peri tells the story of R.L.S. and his American wife, Fanny Van de Grift.
content: A hundred and thirty years after his death, just a few of Robert Louis Stevenson’s books are still widely read: “Treasure Island,” “Kidnapped,” “A Child’s Garden of Verses” and above all his 1886 novella “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” a masterpiece of the grotesque that presaged the coming Freudian era and has exercised a remarkable impact on Anglo-American culture, with some 60 film and television adaptations to date. But Stevenson’s oeuvre was far more extensive. In his short life (he died at just 44, after a lifetime of debilitating illness) he produced a stunning array of novels, short stories, essays, poems and newspaper reportage. His “Complete Works” take up more than three feet on my bookshelf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Hank Sanders
title: A Woman’s Family Reported Her Missing. Her Body Was in Hospital Storage, Lawsuit Says.
description: Jessie Peterson, 31, died at a hospital in April 2023. Her family members, who filed a missing persons report, were not told that she had died until a year later, according to a negligence lawsuit.
content: The family of a woman who died in a California hospital in 2023 said in a lawsuit that they had not been informed that she had died, leading the family members to believe she had been alive and missing for nearly a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In Chicago, Democrats Warn of Threat to Democracy
description: Even amid a more optimistic vibe, convention speakers remind delegates of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: For more than a year, the message from President Biden was dark. The very foundations of the country were at stake in the election, he said. An American apocalypse was on the horizon if former President Donald J. Trump was re-elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Stuber
title: Cycling the Western Balkans: A Wild, Yet Welcoming, Mountain Tour
description: High temperatures and higher mountains were no match for our author and her companion as they biked the Trans Dinarica, a new cycling route that winds through eight countries in the remote Dinaric Alps.
content: “Hey mate!” a cyclist called to us in an Australian accent as he pedaled by on the rocky dirt road that serves as the main street of the village of Theth deep in Albania’s Dinaric Alps. Along with my friend and travel companion, Dave, I had not seen another bikepacker in four days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Three Delegates, Decades Apart in Age, Converge at the Democratic Convention
description: Some participants have been attending for decades, while others will be voting in their first general election this year.
content: Among the nearly 4,700 delegates gathered in Chicago this week for the Democratic National Convention: United States senators and representatives. Top state officials. Leaders of major advocacy groups and labor unions. Democrats aspiring to become one or more of the above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Here’s What to Expect at the Democratic National Convention on Day 3
description: All eyes will be on Gov. Tim Walz as he formally accepts the Democratic Party’s nomination for vice president on Wednesday night.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota will speak to the largest audience of his political career on Wednesday night at the Democratic National Convention, where he will formally accept the party’s nomination for vice president. His speech, on Day 3 of this week’s political coronation at the United Center in Chicago, will be the biggest test so far since Vice President Kamala Harris made the decision to put the jovial, blunt-spoken Midwesterner on the ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Coming Soon to Jersey City: A Gleaming Home for the Symphony
description: The New Jersey Symphony, which long lacked a permanent space, will move into a 550-seat theater that it hopes to make a hub for concerts and classes.
content: The New Jersey Symphony has long lacked a permanent home, performing in a variety of spaces across the state. But come 2026, that will change: The orchestra is getting a gleaming 550-seat theater in downtown Jersey City, the ensemble and the city announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Michelle Obama’s Speech Turns Trump’s ‘Black Jobs’ Line Against Him
description: The former first lady enthralled a packed arena on Tuesday evening with one of the Democratic National Convention’s most emphatic takedowns of Donald J. Trump.
content: Michelle Obama, the former first lady and one of the most popular figures in the Democratic Party, delivered one of the Democratic National Convention’s most emphatic takedowns of former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night and turned one of his most controversial campaign lines against him: “Who’s going to tell him that the job he’s currently seeking might just be one of those ‘Black jobs’?” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein on Barack Obama and Michelle Obama’s Convention Speeches
description: The August 21, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode on the Democratic National Convention. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: Congress Asks Regulators About ‘Troubling’ Health Insurance Tactics
description: Lawmakers are zeroing in on MultiPlan, a firm that has helped insurers cut payments while sometimes leaving patients with large bills.
content: Lawmakers on Tuesday called on health insurance regulators to detail their efforts against “troubling practices” that have raised costs for patients and employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Mishandled Evidence Scuttles Prisoner’s Bid to Prove Innocence
description: Prosecutors in Missouri who sought to free Marcellus Williams faced a setback after DNA analysis did not turn out as they had expected.
content: The new DNA lab report came in two days before Marcellus Williams was supposed to have his day in a suburban St. Louis courtroom, and it was a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Pulls Back Its Electric Vehicle Push
description: The automaker said it would invest less in battery-powered cars and scrap a planned electric three-row sport utility vehicle.
content: Ford Motor, which had once hoped to race ahead of other established automakers in electric vehicles, is again slowing the pace of its investments and new battery-powered models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: How to Bring Out the Best in Your Last Tomatoes of Summer
description: A glut of tomatoes is an embarrassment of riches, especially when put to work in this fragrant curry.
content: When Julius Roberts planted his tomatoes in February, he knew that, come July, he would be greeted by plants much bigger than he is, some growing as tall as two and a half meters. (For the Americans, that’s eight feet and change.) He also knew that, come August, then September, October, even early November, his larder would be spilling over with sunlit fruit as the season’s leaves started to turn and the hot weather relented in the English countryside, where he lives. According to Roberts, a 31-year-old farmer and cook, when you’ve got a good tomato, all you need is olive oil and salt, maybe a piece of toast rubbed with garlic. But when you’ve got a glut of good tomatoes, so many that you can’t keep up, it’s time to reacquaint yourself with the stove and make a curry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Refers More Unruly Passenger Cases to Justice Department
description: A surge in disruptive passenger behavior since the beginning of the pandemic has put pressure on the Federal Aviation Administration.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday that it had asked the Justice Department to consider bringing criminal charges in 43 serious and dangerous incidents from the past year involving unruly passengers aboard  planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Photographer’s Deep Dive Into Murky Waters
description: Michael Turek recently descended 20 feet beneath the waves off New York’s coast to photograph divers who brave the green-tinged waters.
content: When most photographers head out into the field, they pack the essentials: camera lenses, external hard drives, battery chargers, a portable light source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: D.N.C. Schedule Tonight: What Time Tim Walz and Bill Clinton Will Speak
description: The vice-presidential nominee, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, will deliver the night’s closing remarks. Other speakers include former President Bill Clinton and Representative Nancy Pelosi.
content: As is traditional for the third night of a political convention, the headlining speaker of the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday will be the vice-presidential nominee, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul
title: At M.I.T., Black and Latino Enrollment Drops Sharply After Affirmative Action Ban
description: Asian American students made up almost half of the 2028 class — the first admitted since the end of affirmative action.
content: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s incoming class of 2028 saw a precipitous drop-off in the percentage of Black, Hispanic, Native American and Pacific Islander students, the university announced on Wednesday. It is M.I.T.’s first undergraduate class to be admitted since the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision last year banning affirmative action, and M.I.T. is the first major university to release statistics on the composition of its freshman class since the high court’s ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Full Transcript of Michelle Obama’s Speech at the Democratic Convention
description: The former first lady spoke for just over 20 minutes and told the convention that “hope is making a comeback.”
content: OK. We got a big night ahead. Thank you all so much. Thank you so much. OK. There you go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Barack Obama’s Speech Was a Reminder of the Possible
description: Harris is selling something different, but would continue his legacy.
content: The reservoir of good will for Barack Obama is deep in the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Inmate Who Escaped Mississippi Courthouse Is Captured After Standoff in Chicago
description: The authorities had been searching for Joshua Zimmerman, wanted for murder and other crimes, for nearly 70 days. He was barricaded overnight in a restaurant.
content: A man who escaped from a Mississippi courthouse nearly 70 days ago was taken into custody after barricading himself overnight inside a Chicago restaurant less than a mile from where the Democratic National Convention is being held, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Andy Kim, Who Cleaned the Capitol After Jan. 6, Debuts on a Bigger Stage
description: The likely next senator from New Jersey spoke at the Democratic National Convention with a message about the importance of service and participation to safeguard democracy.
content: The first time most Americans were introduced to Representative Andy Kim was in the wee hours of Jan. 7, 2021, when a photographer captured a single image of the bespectacled congressman kneeling alone in the Capitol Rotunda, picking up trash left behind by rioters who had stormed the building just hours earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Courtright
title: ‘Dancing With the Other Arts’: The Ballets Russes’ Creative Churn
description: An exhibition at the Morgan, drawn from its collection of musical manuscripts, sheds light on one of the most collaborative periods in dance.
content: When Robinson McClellan was sifting through the Robert Owen Lehman collection of musical manuscripts at the Morgan Library & Museum in 2019, he came across a concentration of famous ballet scores from the early 20th century. The manuscripts were all connected to the Ballets Russes, the revolutionary dance company founded by the impresario Sergei Diaghilev in Paris, in 1909.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Genoways
title: Vance Thinks He Knows Rural America. Walz Begs to Differ.
description: The Minnesota governor experienced just how much small towns and farming communities rely on public institutions like schools and hospitals.
content: As Tim Walz took the stage at the Astro Theater in the Omaha suburb of La Vista on Saturday afternoon, the crowd roared with approval. Nearly 2,500 people were packed inside the auditorium, and thousands more were watching on big screens outside. It was the first time that Mr. Walz, the Minnesota governor, had been back to the state where he was born and grew up since Kamala Harris tapped him to join the Democratic ticket. He wasted no time in contrasting his running mate’s early years with her opponent Donald Trump’s gilded upbringing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,160
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Day of Week, Date, Year.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Inmates Used Drones to Smuggle Drugs Into Georgia Prisons, U.S. Says
description: The authorities charged nearly two dozen people with taking part in schemes over five years beginning in 2019 to deliver drugs and other contraband to inmates in Georgia state prisons.
content: A network of current and former Georgia inmates used drones to smuggle drugs and other contraband into state prisons, federal prosecutors said Wednesday in announcing charges against nearly two dozen people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should I Take My Share of a Class-Action Settlement I Think Could Be Bogus?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s wrong to participate in a lawsuit you don’t really believe in.
content: I was recently informed via email that I could be entitled to a share of a settlement from a class-action lawsuit. The company being sued denied wrongdoing but agreed to the settlement to avoid an expensive legal battle. I admire this company and have used its product for years. My suspicion is that the lawyers behind the lawsuit are bounty hunters exploiting a technicality. Should I still file for my share of the settlement? (It would be modest — enough to take my husband out for dinner.) If I don’t take my share, everyone else will just get more. — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: For Tim Walz, the Convention Is Like Marrying Into a Very Large Family
description: Every Democrat in Chicago wants to meet him, and maybe give him a hug. “I love him,” one delegate said. “He reminds me of Chris Farley — you know, the man down by the river.”
content: Roughly 50,000 people are converging on Chicago for the Democratic National Convention, and very few of them have ever seen Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Doug Emhoff, Both Earnest and Poking Fun at Himself, Talks Up His Wife
description: The second gentleman drew on his relationship with Kamala Harris in his speech at the Democratic convention, telling a story about a bumbling voice mail message he left her early on.
content: Doug Emhoff, the second gentleman, drew on his decade-old relationship with Vice President Kamala Harris in a passionate pitch for her candidacy on Tuesday night at the Democratic National Convention, urging Americans to follow his lead in trusting her with their families’ futures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Montana Certifies Signatures for November Abortion Question
description: Also on Tuesday, Arizona’s Supreme Court rejected a challenge to a similar ballot measure. That means at least nine states will vote on whether to establish a constitutional right to abortion.
content: Voters in Montana will decide in November whether to enshrine a right to abortion in the state Constitution, joining eight other states with similar citizen-sponsored questions on their ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: He Tried to ‘Walk the Line Between Elder Statesman and Queen Maker’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 2 of the Convention
description: Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Bernie Sanders, Chuck Schumer, Doug Emhoff and Michelle and Barack Obama.
content: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 2 of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Kamala Harris; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Bernie Sanders, Chuck Schumer, Doug Emhoff and Michelle and Barack Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Can High Prices and Health Scares Keep Americans From Their Deli Meat?
description: Sales dropped after the Boar’s Head recall, but as parents go back to packing school lunches, don’t bet against this popular staple.
content: It’s been a roller coaster of a month for lunch meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Taylor Robinson and Alyce McFadden
title: Here Is the Kamala Harris Roll Call Playlist
description: As each state delegation was called on, the moment was accompanied by a song.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Tim Walz’s Superpower
description: Walz has an easy masculine confidence we seem to have all but forgotten.
content: One is an N.F.L. tight end who cries openly and holds his girlfriend’s purse, when he’s not carrying one of his own. The other is a former high-school football coach and National Guardsman who speaks openly about his infertility journey, supports gay rights and was responsible for bringing free period products into Minnesota’s public schools — which resulted in him being cast as “Tampon Tim.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Liberals Needed a Beyoncé Moment. Kamala Harris Is Delivering One.
description: The vice president is giving Democrats what they want while disorienting Donald Trump.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris made a surprise appearance on Monday night at the Democratic National Convention, she walked onstage to the sound of Beyoncé’s “Freedom,” a 2016 song that The Independent said “roars like thunder, and threatens to topple governments in its wake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 438
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Delegates ‘Get Low’ With Lil Jon in a Musical Roll-Call Vote for Harris
description: The rapper, representing Georgia, briefly stole the show in Chicago with a surprise performance during a lively yet symbolic vote. Vice President Kamala Harris is already the party’s nominee.
content: The rapper Lil Jon burst onto the floor of the Democratic convention on Tuesday night, singing a few bars of his iconic song “Turn Down for What” as delegates roared in excitement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts and Joseph P. Fried
title: Bill Pascrell Jr., 14-Term House Democrat From N.J., Dies at 87
description: An outspoken progressive, he vigorously opposed President Donald J. Trump and focused on legislation to help “regular Americans pay their bills.”
content: Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a blunt progressive Democrat from northern New Jersey who was poised to become the oldest member of the House of Representatives, died on Wednesday in Livingston, N.J. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Explaining Claims About Tim Walz’s Military Service
description: Four veterans who investigate claims of fraudulent military service said they do not believe the governor is guilty of “stolen valor,” but that he did misrepresent his record at times.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has faced fresh scrutiny over his military service, and how he has characterized his record, in the weeks since he was selected as Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth Harris
title: ‘A Lot of Us Are Gone’: How the Push to Diversify Publishing Fell Short
description: Lisa Lucas was among the big hires meant to shake up the industry. Her departure, alongside other prominent Black editors and executives, has led some to question publishers’ pledge to diversify.
content: When Lisa Lucas was hired in the summer of 2020 to take a big job at the country’s largest book publisher, there was a sense that things were finally starting to change in what has long been an overwhelmingly white industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What’s in the Latest U.S. Proposal for a Gaza Cease-Fire?
description: The Biden administration is pushing for a deal between Israel and Hamas with renewed urgency after months of lagging talks. Here’s a closer look at what the main differences appear to be.
content: The Biden administration is pushing again for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, offering a new proposal that it says could bridge the gaps between the two sides. But the latest U.S. effort, which builds on an earlier framework, again appears to have run into difficulty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Charlene Marshall, Central Figure in a Celebrity Scandal, Dies at 79
description: Her husband, Anthony, was convicted of defrauding his wealthy mother, Brooke Astor. But in the tabloids, Mrs. Marshall often seemed to be the one on trial.
content: Charlene Marshall, who played a central role in a high-profile civil suit and subsequent criminal trial in which her husband, Anthony, was convicted of defrauding his mother, the wealthy socialite Brooke Astor, died on Aug. 6 at her home in Northeast Harbor, Maine. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Added 818,000 Fewer Jobs Than Reported Earlier
description: The Labor Department issued revised figures for the 12 months through March that point to greater economic fragility.
content: The U.S. economy added far fewer jobs in 2023 and early 2024 than previously reported, a sign that cracks in the labor market are more severe — and began forming earlier — than initially believed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Thailand Reports Mpox Case in Traveler Who Arrived From Africa
description: Officials are testing if the patient has the new version of the virus. If confirmed, it would be Thailand’s first case involving Clade Ib mpox.
content: Thailand reported on Wednesday a case of mpox suspected to be caused by the new and potentially more deadly version of the virus. If confirmed, it would be the first such case in Thailand and would come a week after the World Health Organization declared the disease a global health emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Peltola Finishes First in Alaska House Primary, With Begich as Top Challenger
description: The conservative son of a prominent liberal Alaska political family came in second in a ranked-choice primary that could play out similarly to 2022, when Republicans split their votes and elected a Democrat.
content: Representative Mary Peltola, Democrat of Alaska, ranked first on Tuesday in an open primary to set the field for her re-election bid, claiming just over 50 percent of the vote in preliminary results, well ahead of 11 challengers vying for her position as the state’s sole member of the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien and Michael Gold
title: Trump Attacks Harris at N.C. Rally, Asking the Crowd to Back Him Up
description: In a speech intended to be about national security, Mr. Trump continued personal attacks on Kamala Harris and asked for validation in doing so from the crowd.
content: After two days of policy-focused addresses with modest crowds, former President Donald J. Trump returned to form on Wednesday with an outdoor speech in North Carolina, where he insisted that he would not give up personal attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris and continued to sow doubts about the integrity of the election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Hadley Duvall Says Her Abortion Speech Will ‘Keep My Heart Full’
description: Ms. Duvall, a sexual abuse survivor, was one of three women who shared their personal stories at the Democratic convention to support Vice President Kamala Harris.
content: There was Hadley Duvall, calm and measured, hand in her pocket, as she recounted the violence that she endured before becoming one of the most prominent voices of the fight for abortion rights in her home state of Kentucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: The Convention’s Happiest Democrats? The ‘Pretty Psyched’ Minnesotans.
description: The unexpected rise of a native son, Tim Walz, has thrilled his local compatriots in Chicago. “The Minnesota delegation is, like, buzzing,” said Senator Tina Smith.
content: The Georgia delegates danced with the rapper Lil Jon at the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday. The Wisconsin delegates cheered in their Cheesehead hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Russia Says Ukraine Aimed Drones at Moscow
description: Plus, China’s “road-trip auntie.”
content: Russia said it repelled a drone attack against Moscow yesterday, as Ukraine presses on with its offensive in Russia’s southern Kursk region. The Russian authorities did not report any damage or casualties, saying 10 Ukrainian attack drones were destroyed by the capital’s air defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Minutes Show a Cut ‘Likely’ to Come in September
description: Even before a disappointing July jobs report, Federal Reserve officials thought they would probably cut rates at their Sept. 17-18 meeting.
content: Federal Reserve officials held off on cutting interest rates at their July meeting, but minutes from that gathering showed that they were clearly poised to lower them at their meeting in September, just weeks before the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Obamas Strike Back
description: Could the former first couple’s convention speeches signal a return to Obamaism?
content: Is Obamaism making a comeback? Tuesday night at the Democratic National Convention, Michelle and Barack Obama electrified the crowd with the most powerful speeches of the week so far, and seemed to anoint Kamala Harris as the inheritor of their political movement. For this audio diary, I’m joined by my producer Elias Isquith to dissect those two speeches. We discuss what Obamaism was in 2008 and 2012, and what it means to pass the baton to Harris in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Convention Insider: Lauren Underwood Is Right at Home in Chicago
description: The congresswoman is in her home city, and has been a selfie magnet for sorority sisters and young Democrats.
content: Lauren Underwood was running late, but she couldn’t not stop for a selfie. Or five.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angad Singh and James Robinson
title: Why Kamala Harris’s Mom Was More ‘Brat’ Than She Is
description: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.
content: Young voters have been embracing Kamala Harris for her “brat” energy, invoking a trend popularized by the musician Charli XCX. But could Ms. Harris’s mom actually be more “brat” than she is? In the Opinion Video above, the journalist Angad Singh digs into this question by examining her Indian heritage to better understand the current momentum behind Ms. Harris’s campaign. Mr. Singh argues that this momentum “could easily fizzle if she doesn’t lay out policies that distinguish her from her predecessor, who was decidedly not ‘brat’ enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Hard Work and Fizzy Drinks: What It Takes to Live Past 110
description: They are called supercentenarians, and they have seen it all.
content: One of the oldest men in the world died in August at the age of 111. The man, John Farringdon, was born about a year after the Titanic sank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: China’s ‘Road Trip Auntie’ Is Ready for a New Milestone: Divorce
description: Su Min became an internet sensation for leaving behind an abusive husband to drive across China alone. Now she’s ending the marriage, but there will be a price.
content: In the four years since she began driving solo across China, leaving behind an abusive marriage and longstanding expectations about women’s duties at home, Su Min, 60, has become an internet sensation known as the “road-trip auntie.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 21, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024.
content: An article on Tuesday about Hillary Clinton’s bond with Kamala Harris referred incorrectly to dinners hosted by the Clintons at their home in Washington. Douglas Elmendorf, the former dean at Harvard Kennedy School, says he was not in attendance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Said It Repelled a Large Ukrainian Drone Attack on Moscow
description: The attack came as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive into western Russia that has rattled the Kremlin.
content: Russia said on Wednesday that Moscow had come under a sizable drone attack overnight, as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive far from the capital that has rattled the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Paramount Extends Talks With New Bidder, Unsettling Skydance Deal
description: Edgar Bronfman Jr. and his bidding group now have until September to sell Paramount on their offer.
content: Paramount on Wednesday decided to extend its deadline to evaluate a takeover bid from the media executive Edgar Bronfman Jr., the company said,  a sign that the company is taking the offer seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Under a Frozen Army Base, He Found Incredible Fossils
description: In a new book, geologist Paul Bierman recounts the moment he found astonishing evidence that Greenland’s ice sheet had melted in the ancient past.
content: Somewhere deep inside a glacier in Greenland are the remains of Camp Century, a short-lived experiment in making the Cold War literal. In 1959, the U.S. Army began building a network of tunnels, carved inside the ice, that it hoped might become a launch site for nuclear missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Convention Insider: Chuck Schumer Takes Chicago
description: Nearly 800 miles from home in Brooklyn, the Senate majority leader found friends galore at the convention.
content: Standing in the middle of an outdoor bar in an alleyway in Chicago, Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, looked around and remarked: “Nice city. It’s not New York, but it’s a nice city.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Who’s the Change Candidate?
description: Inside the fight over who most represents change ahead of November.
content: It’s hard for the party that holds the White House to run as the party of change. But Kamala Harris and the Democrats are trying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Kenny Holston
title: The Small-Town Nebraska Tim Walz Put Behind Him, but Never Fully Left
description: A political persona forged on the prairie: self-assured but rarely self-serious; puckish when possible, stoic when necessary.
content: Tim Walz was 14 or so, trouble-seeking with his cousins across a shaggy patch of family land where they liked to shoot air guns at birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Al Attles, a Golden State Warrior in Name and in Spirit, Dies at 87
description: He was known as the Destroyer for his gritty intensity as a player. He later coached Golden State to an N.B.A. championship and served as its general manager.
content: Al Attles, a Basketball Hall of Fame guard who was among the most prominent figures in the history of the Golden State Warriors and their forerunner franchise in Philadelphia, died on Tuesday at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman and Erika Solomon
title: Hundreds of Ultra-Orthodox Israelis Clash With Police Over Draft
description: Protests over military conscription highlight the rising tensions surrounding a court order overturning a decades-long exemption for the religious community.
content: Hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Israeli men protested outside a conscription center in Jerusalem on Wednesday and clashed with police officers amid rising national tensions about a court decision ordering a draft for the insular community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: 4 Questions to Ask Before Reuniting With an Ex-Partner
description: As Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck show, rekindling an old romance is risky. We asked couples counselors what you should ask before diving back in.
content: When the superstars Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck married in 2022, decades after calling off their initial engagement, it seemed like the stuff of a romantic Hollywood blockbuster.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Braving the Wild to Rescue the Rarest of Flowers
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 21, 2024.
content: “It’s not that I am that daring. These situations just arise, and they are not like Superman extreme. Sometimes it’s more Peter Sellers than Indiana Jones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: The Year of the A.I. Election That Wasn’t
description: More than 30 tech companies have pitched A.I. tools to political campaigns for November’s election. The campaigns have been wary.
content: Matthew Diemer, a Democrat running for election in Ohio’s Seventh Congressional District, was approached by the artificial intelligence company Civox in January with a pitch: A.I.-backed voice technology that could make tens of thousands of personalized phone calls to voters using Mr. Diemer’s talking points and sense of humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Advocates for Palestinians vie for attention at the Democratic convention.
description: delegates from Uncommitted, a movement calling for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza and an arms embargo on Israel, are demanding that a speaker of Palestinian descent address the convention from the main stage, as relatives of a hostage being held in Gaza spoke on Wednesday evening.
content: Behind the scenes at the Democratic National Convention, delegates from Uncommitted, a movement calling for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza and an arms embargo on Israel, demanded that a speaker of Palestinian descent address the convention from the main stage, as relatives of a hostage being held in Gaza spoke on Wednesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: For Historic Gardens, Climate Change Offers Particular Challenges
description: At Wethersfield Estate, in upstate New York, restoring the formal gardens involves dealing with emboldened pests and pathogens — but carefully, so visitors don’t see.
content: A walk through the formal gardens at Wethersfield Estate & Garden, in Amenia, N.Y., offers a dreamy escape back in time. The landscape, some 80 years in the making, conjures the Italian Renaissance and hints of ancient Greece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: If Dire Warnings Won’t Stop Trump, Democrats Figure Mockery Might
description: The passing of the torch from President Biden to Vice President Kamala Harris has been accompanied by another change: the reintroduction of humor.
content: If Democrats can’t make the nation fear Donald Trump, they have decided that perhaps they can persuade voters to laugh at him instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: ‘I Am the Only Person Stupid Enough to Speak After Michelle Obama’
description: So said former President Barack Obama after his wife electrified the Democratic National Convention. The delegates loved him, but they really loved her.
content: Whoever set the schedule for the second night of the Democratic National Convention certainly did Barack Obama no favors. As the former president admitted when he took the stage on Tuesday night, “I am the only person stupid enough to speak after Michelle Obama.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russia Seeks to Turn Humbling Incursion Into Military Gains
description: Two weeks after Ukraine launched its surprise attack, Russian forces have recovered from the initial shock and are trying to use the expanding war to their battlefield advantage.
content: Two weeks after Ukraine’s surprise incursion into Russia, the Kremlin’s forces have slowed the advance, with the hardening front line in the Kursk region of Russia setting up the next phase of a battle with great political stakes for both sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: We All Live in Vegas Now
description: America is becoming a nation of gamblers. Why?
content: In 2022, Americans lost $60 billion betting at licensed casinos and through licensed online gambling, Nate Silver writes in his engrossing new book, “On the Edge,” a meditation on risk, a study of those most comfortable taking it and an invitation for the rest of us to think about what it means that so much more of our lives now seems to hang on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Is Leaving the Spotlight. His Son’s Legal Troubles Are Not.
description: A preliminary hearing on Wednesday will determine the contours of the tax trial Hunter Biden faces in September. It is often a forum for discussions that could lead to a plea deal.
content: Hunter Biden watched backstage in Chicago on Monday night as his father, President Biden, strode into the spotlight of the Democratic National Convention to bask in the appreciation of the party’s faithful and to gain a measure of closure after an unforgiving 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: A Bookshop Cancels an Event Over a Rabbi’s Zionism, Prompting Outrage
description: Shortly before a talk between a Jewish author and a liberal rabbi, a manager at Powerhouse Arena in Brooklyn barred the rabbi from participating, saying, “We don’t want a Zionist onstage.”
content: Shortly before 6 on Tuesday evening, Joshua Leifer was on his way to an event for his new book, “Tablets Shattered: The End of an American Jewish Century and the Future of Jewish Life,” when he got a call from his publicist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ex-Babysitter Gets 3 Years in Prison in 2019 Death of Man She Injured as a Baby
description: Terry McKirchy, 62, violently shook Benjamin Dowling while babysitting for him in 1984, prosecutors said. She was charged with murder after he died from his injuries 35 years later.
content: A former babysitter in Florida was sentenced on Wednesday to three years in prison after she pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the 2019 death of a man whom she had disabled as an infant 35 years earlier, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Benjamin Mullin
title: Investors Brace for a Jobs Wipeout
description: Economists forecast that a revision to payrolls data could undercut a robust picture of the labor market, further pressuring the Federal Reserve to cut rates.
content: The torrid weeklong stocks rally has taken a breather as investors again shift their focus to the weakening labor market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Studio Pulls ‘Megalopolis’ Trailer Featuring Fake Review Quotes
description: To promote Francis Ford Coppola’s epic, the spot used supposed lines from The Times, The New Yorker and others to suggest critics were wrong about him.
content: A new trailer for Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis” featuring fake negative quotes from film critics has been pulled by the movie’s distributor, Lionsgate, a spokesman for the company said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: ‘Worst-Case’ Disaster for Antarctic Ice Looks Less Likely, Study Finds
description: Global warming is putting the continent’s ice at risk of destruction in many forms. But one especially calamitous scenario might be a less pressing concern, a new study found.
content: For almost a decade, climate scientists have been trying to get their heads around a particularly disastrous scenario for how West Antarctica’s gigantic ice sheet might break apart, bringing catastrophe to the world’s coasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A ‘Speedy Little Star’ May Be on Course to Escape Our Galaxy
description: The so-called hypervelocity object, which is either a low-mass star or a brown dwarf, is traveling through the Milky Way at around a million miles an hour.
content: In his spare time, Tom Bickle, an astronomy student in Southampton, England, likes to blast heavy metal while combing through time-lapses of the night sky, hunting for traces of a hypothesized ninth planet and other hidden objects lurking in the outskirts of our solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Islam Al-Atrash
title: Fight for Control of Central Bank Threatens Libya’s Uneasy Peace
description: The country has settled into a tense east-west divide, but turmoil around the central bank, which handles Libya’s oil riches, has worsened a fraying, fragile political setup.
content: Libya has scarcely known peace or stability since rebels overthrew its longtime dictator during the 2011 Arab Spring uprisings. After a civil war that ended in 2020, Libya remains split between rival, mutually hostile governments, one in the west and one in the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: What ‘It Ends With Us’ Gets Wrong (and Right) About Domestic Abuse
description: Its depiction of love-bombing and psychological abuse rings true, experts say, but other oversimplified aspects could send a dangerous message.
content: A person trying to escape an abusive relationship, on average, needs seven attempts to actually leave. Lily Bloom, the protagonist of the new drama “It Ends With Us,” needs only one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Danielle Kaye
title: Consumers Are Still Bargain Shopping, Macy’s and Target Reports Show
description: Department store chains have struggled as Americans, squeezed by budget constraints, spend less time and money at their stores.
content: As U.S. consumers navigate an economy still rocked by high inflation, they are guided by tight wallets and cheaper goods, a trend that’s hitting department store chains like Macy’s harder than discount retailers like Target and T.J. Maxx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Michelle Obama Suits the Moment
description: On Day 2 of the Democratic National Convention, the former first lady (and her husband) suited up for the next stage.
content: From the moment Michelle Obama strode onstage at the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday night baring arms, her appearance and her words were a reminder of why she had been such a powerful communicator as a first lady — and as a writer and speaker thereafter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Did You Meet Someone Special This Summer?
description: Do you have a summer meet-cute story? Whether it was a chance encounter at the beach or a spontaneous date that turned into something more, we want to hear about your summer romances.
content: In June, The New York Times published a list of hot spots in New York to meet people. Many people are longing for organic, in-person connections, but they don’t necessarily know where to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Debbie Mucarsel-Powell Wins the Democratic Senate Nomination in Florida
description: The former congresswoman will challenge the Republican incumbent, Rick Scott, in November.
content: Debbie Mucarsel-Powell, a former one-term congresswoman from Miami, won the Democratic nomination in the race for U.S. Senate in Florida on Tuesday, setting up a challenge against Rick Scott, the Republican incumbent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Hannah Gadsby: Woof’ Review: A Comic’s Pet Themes
description: In a soul-baring new show at the Edinburgh Fringe, the Australian stand-up leans once again into fears, anxieties and mental health worries.
content: The title of Hannah Gadsby’s new stand-up show at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is “Woof,” but the Australian comic has a very specific type of dog bark in mind. It sounds like something between a burp and a cough. It’s impossible to spell, but if you had to, it might go something like “peuh.” Gadsby says it typically signals that the animal is about to go into a frenzy. As a metaphor for Gadsby’s state of mind, it’s inauspicious. Should we be concerned?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
title: While the Public Awaited Jobs Data, Wall Street Firms Got a Look
description: A report was delayed on the Bureau of Labor Statistics website, but some investors got it in the meantime, raising new questions about agency practices.
content: For more than half an hour on Wednesday morning, economists and investors were stuck repeatedly refreshing their browsers, looking for a delayed report on the U.S. job market from a government website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Maggie Haberman and Benjamin Oreskes
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Expected to End His Presidential Campaign
description: Short on cash and losing traction with voters, Mr. Kennedy intends to make a speech about his political future on Friday.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is expected to end his troubled independent presidential campaign this week, according to three people briefed on his plans, and is in talks to throw his support behind former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Ex-U.S. Airman Charged With Child Pornography Appears in Russian Propaganda Video
description: “I don’t consider myself a traitor,” said Wilmer Puello-Mota, who has enlisted in the Russian military.
content: A former U.S. Air Force airman who absconded to Russia after being hit with child pornography charges appears to be featured in a Russian propaganda video in which he defends his decision to enlist in the military there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rowena Chiu
title: I Was a Celebrity Assistant. The Power Imbalance Is Very Real.
description: I was Harvey Weinstein’s assistant. I understand all too well the toxic nature of the relationship between celebrities and the people they employ.
content: Earlier this month, Kenneth Iwamasa, 59, the live-in assistant to the actor Matthew Perry, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to distribute ketamine, the drug that led to the death of his employer. Very few people have firsthand insight into the toxic dynamic that can develop while assisting a celebrity or understand the inherent power imbalance that can arise. I do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: New Speculative Fiction About the Villainous Power of Universities
description: Our columnist takes a look at recent books by Sofia Samatar, Vajra Chandrasekera and Emet North.
content: I feel privileged to witness the emergence of a type of fiction — not a genre, exactly, but an affect — that I might call, in the manner of a Spotify daylist, “queer millennial midlife multiversal crisis.” In it I would pile Isaac Fellman’s “The Two Doctors Górski,” Aimee Pokwatka’s “Self-Portrait With Nothing” and Jo Harkin’s “Tell Me an Ending” — all books that present selves and universes in a state of fracture, asking what if in a way that also demands why, though.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Yu
title: How to Exercise During Menopause
description: Your body changes during the menopause transition. So should your fitness routine.
content: When Alison Gittelman turned 49, she found that she couldn’t run as fast or as long as she had before. She was an experienced marathoner and triathlete, but suddenly, as she entered menopause, her heart rate was unusually elevated while running. Her joints hurt. She gained weight. She started experiencing debilitating menstrual cramps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: U.S. Army Soldier Is Charged With Lying About Ties to Insurrectionist Group
description: The soldier, Kai Liam Nix, 20, who was stationed at Fort Liberty in North Carolina, is also accused of illegally selling firearms.
content: An active duty U.S. Army soldier has been charged with lying to the military about his ties to a group dedicated to overthrowing the government and with illegally selling firearms, according to federal prosecutors in North Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: As N.Y.C. Reading Scores Slip Under New Program, Officials Urge Patience
description: Math scores notched upward in the city, and officials said the drop in reading was explained in part by an effort to change reading instruction and retrain hundreds of teachers.
content: Fewer than half of New York City public school students showed proficiency on reading exams this year, a decline from the previous year that may reflect how hard it is to change teaching approaches as the district embarks on a major reading overhaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For Aja Naomi King, an Emmy Nomination Is a Seismic Event
description: The earth shook as she talked about receiving her first Emmy nod, for her role as Harriet in the Apple TV+ show “Lessons in Chemistry.” Literally.
content: Voting is underway for the 76th Primetime Emmys, and this week we are talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 15 on ABC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Man Who U.S. Says Faked Death to Avoid Child Support Gets 81 Months in Prison
description: The man, Jesse Kipf, hacked into state death registry systems to fake his own death in part to avoid paying more than $100,000 in child support, federal prosecutors said.
content: A Kentucky man who prosecutors say hacked into state death registry systems to fake his own death — in part to avoid paying more than $100,000 in child support — was sentenced on Monday to 81 months in federal prison, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Armstrong
title: 7 Days in the Cultural Life of an Artistic Director
description: Violaine Huisman, who leads programming for the Crossing the Line festival, takes in dance on Little Island, a world premiere at Asia Society and “invigorating” translation projects.
content: Bastille Day felt a little bit different this year than others, said Violaine Huisman, the artistic director of New York’s annual Crossing the Line festival. L’Alliance New York, the French cultural center in Midtown, throws a party every July 14, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille during the French Revolution. This year, the celebration took place just one week after a surprising snap election left President Emmanuel Macron — and France — in a state of flux.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What Sex Therapists Wish You Knew
description: We asked nearly a dozen experts in sex and intimacy for the advice they repeat again and again. For starters, they said, don’t get so hung up on how often you have, or want, sex.
content: Couples worried about “mismatched” libidos. People struggling to orgasm. Lovers wondering if they’re having a “normal” amount of sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Could That Garage Be Apartments? New York Hunts for Places to Build.
description: Mayor Eric Adams signed an executive order that directs every city agency to investigate whether they have land that can be developed.
content: New York City is turning to its own properties — including libraries, parking lots and garages — in a desperate search for space to build new homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Nancy Pelosi Interrupted by Pro-Palestinian Protesters on ‘The Late Show’
description: “Isn’t it great to be in Chicago?” the former House speaker exclaimed in her appearance with Stephen Colbert, an apparent attempt to defuse the tension.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Investigating Americans Who Worked With Russian State Television
description: The F.B.I. raided the homes of two prominent commentators on Russian state television channels as part of an effort to blunt attempts to influence November’s election.
content: The Department of Justice has begun a broad criminal investigation into Americans who have worked with Russia’s state television networks, signaling an aggressive effort to combat the Kremlin’s influence operations leading up to the presidential election in November, according to American officials briefed on the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Divers Find 4 Bodies From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
description: The discoveries came after the vessel went down this week in what some witnesses described as a waterspout, or a small tornado, during a violent downpour. No names were immediately released.
content: After three days of searching the hull of a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily, divers on Wednesday recovered the bodies of four passengers who were believed to have been trapped inside their cabins when the vessel went down, officials in Sicily said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: The second night of the Democratic National Convention.
content: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How U.S. Farms Could Start a Bird Flu Pandemic
description: The virus is poised to become a permanent presence in cattle, raising the odds of an eventual outbreak among people.
content: Without a sharp pivot in state and federal policies, the bird flu virus that has bedeviled American farms is likely to find a firm foothold among dairy cattle, scientists are warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Isn’t Finished
description: The damage inflicted on the nation during the former president’s first term in office pales in comparison to what he will do if he is elected to a second term.
content: The damage inflicted on the nation during Donald Trump’s first term in office pales in comparison with what he will do if he is elected to a second term. How can we know this? The best evidence is Trump himself. He has repeatedly demonstrated his willingness to tear the country apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: An Easy Buttermilk Peach Cobbler to Whip Up on a Weeknight
description: It’s just about the summery-est thing you can do with the last of the season’s stone fruits.
content: If discerning the difference between a crumble and a crisp is one fruit-filled conundrum, here’s another: Where’s the line between a caky peach cobbler made with a batter, and a buttery, one-bowl peach cake served warm with a spoon?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Hayasaki
title: She Survived the Maui Wildfires. She Couldn’t Survive the Year After.
description: Edralina Diezon was working as a janitor and sending money to her family in the Philippines when wildfires destroyed everything she had. The road to rebuilding her life proved to be perilous.
content: As a whirlwind of flames nearly encircled the Lahaina Gateway shopping center on Aug. 8, 2023, Edralina Diezon hid in a storage room, surrounded by mops, buckets and brooms. Terrified, Ms. Diezon, who worked 80 hours a week as a janitor, did not leave for two days and two nights. When she finally emerged, starving and disoriented, the neighborhood where she lived was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Something in the Air
description: Stacey Yaruss McCullough makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gunman Kills 3 People at School in Bosnia
description: The attacker, a school employee, used a “military weapon, an automatic rifle” before then attempting to kill himself, a police spokesman said.
content: A school employee shot dead three people on Wednesday in a town in northwestern Bosnia, the police said, and was then severely wounded after trying to kill himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: Women’s Cricket World Cup Moved From Bangladesh Because of Unrest
description: The United Arab Emirates will host the tournament after many governments advised against traveling to Bangladesh.
content: The International Cricket Council on Tuesday moved the 2024 Women’s T20 World Cup to the United Arab Emirates because of the ongoing political instability and security concerns in Bangladesh, which was scheduled to host the tournament in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why Manhattan College Is Changing Its Name
description: Colleges competing for international students prefer to be known as universities.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why, after 171 years, Manhattan College is getting a new name. We’ll also look at why Amtrak’s system keeps breaking down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Divert Great Lakes Water to California?
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about dealing with groundwater depletion. Also: Feeling hopeful; no comparison between medals; nix “no problem.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Harris Goes Light on Climate Policy. Green Leaders Are OK With That.
description: President Biden made climate change a cornerstone of his agenda. Vice President Kamala Harris has yet to detail her own plan.
content: In the 2020 presidential election, climate activists demanded that Democratic candidates explain, in detail, how they planned to tackle the planet’s greatest environmental threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Donations Soared for Harris After Biden Dropped Out
description: When Vice President Kamala Harris became the party’s nominee, the money started to flow.
content: Joe Biden’s decision on July 21 to drop out of the presidential race unleashed a gusher of cash that fundamentally changed the money race between Democrats and former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: The Party’s After-Parties: Once Dreary Democrats Remember How to Have Fun
description: “This is a group that’s not used to being happy — they’re used to complaining,” one reveler noted. For now, at least, the rise of Kamala Harris has changed that.
content: “There’s nothing wrong with being over-excited.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Should We Tell Our Tween Daughter That Her Father Had a Nose Job?
description: When a couple’s 12-year-old starts to point out that no one else in the family seems to have a nose like hers, they can’t agree whether to tell her why.
content: My husband and I grew up in the 1980s, when getting a nose job was not uncommon in our social circles. My husband had one. Our daughter is 12, and she has her father’s original nose. Lately, she’s told us that she doesn’t love her nose and that it’s unlike anyone else’s in the family. My husband wants to tell her about his surgery — with the proviso that he would make a different choice today. But I think he should keep it to himself. I don’t see how sharing this information would help our daughter, and it may harm her. Still, I know this is my husband’s story to tell. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: They Spouted Hate Online. Then They Were Arrested.
description: As hundreds of people appear in court for their role in recent anti-immigrant riots in Britain, several are accused of fueling disorder through online posts, raising questions about the limits of free speech.
content: A 53-year-old woman from northwest England was jailed for 15 months after posting on Facebook that a mosque should be blown up “with the adults inside.” A 45-year-old man was sentenced to 20 months for goading his online followers to torch a hotel that houses refugees. A 55-year-old woman was questioned by the police for a viral post that wrongly identified the suspect in a deadly knife attack at a children’s dance class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Grandchildren of Two Past Democratic Presidents Say Harris Is Party’s Future
description: Jack Schlossberg, grandson of John F. Kennedy, and Jason Carter, grandson of Jimmy Carter, told the Democratic convention on Tuesday that Kamala Harris was the natural heir to their ancestors’ legacy.
content: Grandchildren of two Democratic presidents — John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter — helped to open the second night of the Democratic convention on Tuesday by presenting Vice President Kamala Harris as a natural heir to the legacy of both of these former leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Bus of Pilgrims From Pakistan Crashes in Iran, Killing at Least 28
description: Iranian state media reported that the passengers were traveling to the Iraqi city of Karbala for Arbaeen, a Shiite Muslim holiday.
content: At least 28 pilgrims from Pakistan were killed in Iran when their bus overturned on Tuesday night while traveling to commemorate a Shiite Muslim holiday, state-run media in Iran has reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Stopped Busing Migrants to Democratic Cities in Late June
description: Gov. Greg Abbott’s busing program forced Democrats to talk about the border. But a dramatic drop in the number of migrants has left the buses idle.
content: Despite the concerns of some Democratic leaders and city officials in Chicago, the state of Texas has not sent buses filled with migrants to the city this week during the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: Walmart Dumps Entire Stake in China’s JD.com
description: Walmart has divested as its e-commerce partner has struggled to maintain its market share in the country’s cutthroat online sales industry.
content: Walmart said it unloaded its entire stake in JD.com, one of China’s biggest e-commerce companies, unwinding one of the largest investments in a Chinese retailer by a foreign rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Bill Clinton Hails Harris as ‘President of Joy’ but Warns Against Overconfidence
description: The former president cautioned exuberant delegates at the Democratic National Convention not to be complacent in 2024 because politics is “a brutal, tough business.”
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: How Gaza Is Showing Up in Chicago
description: So far, the D.N.C. does not feature the chaos many feared, but protesters and uncommitted delegates are pushing their cause.
content: After two days of the Democratic National Convention, one thing is clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith, Ernesto Londoño and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Protesters March Again in Chicago One Night After Dozens Were Arrested
description: At least 55 demonstrators protesting the Democratic convention were detained on Tuesday after scuffling with the police outside Israel’s consulate. Hundreds more marched Wednesday.
content: The Chicago police arrested at least 55 people, including three journalists, at a protest outside the city’s Israeli consulate on Tuesday night, officials said on Wednesday hours before another protest began near the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Democrats Look to Redefine Trump
description: Also, the U.S. added far fewer jobs than previously reported. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: For nearly a decade, Democrats have tried to persuade voters that Donald Trump is a villain, a racist and a threat to democracy. Now, with Kamala Harris atop the ticket, the vice president and her allies are trying something new: They are looking to deflate him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Kamala Harris Is Trying to Claim the Mantle of Change
description: Ms. Harris is working to embody a powerful political force. But Donald J. Trump doesn’t want to let the incumbent party sell itself as anything but the status quo.
content: The fight over whether Kamala Harris can represent change has emerged as one of the early thematic battlegrounds of the 2024 race, playing out both at this week’s Democratic convention in Chicago and on the airwaves of swing states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Wasu Vipoosanapat
title: Thai Politician Is Under Fire After Slapping a Journalist on Camera
description: Videos of Prawit Wongsuwan, a former deputy prime minister, hitting a female reporter in the head prompted angry demands for an investigation in Thailand.
content: A politician is surrounded by journalists while walking down a corridor when one of them asks him a question. Instead of answering it, he raises his hand and slaps her in the head several times before climbing into his vehicle and driving away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Michelle Obama Absolutely Takes Apart Donald Trump
description: No doublespeak, no metaphors — just straight talk.
content: In 2007, a young biracial senator from Illinois named Barack Obama was trying to convince Black voters that he was one of them. I traveled to South Carolina to see a set of speeches that would become a historic inflection point — Oprah and Michelle Obama code-switching to tell the state’s Black Democrats that he was the real deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Andrew E. Kramer, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Inside Ukraine’s Invasion of Russia
description: What the unlikely incursion could mean for the war.
content: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How Did the First Cells Arise? With a Little Rain, Study Finds.
description: Researchers stumbled upon an ingredient that can stabilize droplets of genetic material: water.
content: Rain may have been an essential ingredient for the origin of life, according to a study published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: On Harris’s Price-Gouging Ban, Allies and Foes May Have the Wrong Idea
description: The plan does not appear to amount to government price controls. It also might not bring down grocery bills anytime soon.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris threw her support behind a federal ban on price-gouging in the food and grocery industries last week. It was the first official economic policy proposal of her presidential campaign, and it was pitched as a direct response to the high price of putting food on the table in America today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Arrests Man Over Disinformation That Helped Spur U.K. Riots
description: Local police sources indicated that the arrest was made at the request of the British authorities, although there was no official confirmation.
content: The Pakistani authorities arrested a man this week on charges of cyberterrorism for spreading fake news that helped set off violent riots in Britain following a deadly stabbing attack last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in Oregon, North Carolina and Massachusetts
description: A 1911 Arts and Crafts estate in Portland, a four-bedroom home in Charlotte and an 1870 brick townhouse in Boston.
content: This home, listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is in Mount Tabor, about 15 minutes from downtown. It is a few blocks from a dog park and walking trails with sweeping city views in Mount Tabor Park, and within walking distance of a public elementary school, an Irish pub, restaurants that serve tacos and dumplings, and a movie rental shop. An H Mart supermarket is five minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: prolific
description: This word has appeared in 738 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word prolific has appeared in 738 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 18 in “Can You Retire if You Never Had a Job? NOFX Will Try” by James H. Martin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, David E. Sanger, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: The Obamas’ Back-to-Back Speeches, and a Secret U.S. Nuclear Defense Plan
description: Plus, why eating meat may raise diabetes risk.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Convention Insider: Ro Khanna Never Skips Breakfast
description: The Silicon Valley congressman is spending his time going to 15 state delegation breakfasts and maybe, just maybe, laying groundwork for higher office.
content: As Representative Ro Khanna of California left a Michigan delegation breakfast this week after giving a brief speech, he was humble about the impression he had made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris, in a Show of Force, Holds a Large Rally 80 Miles From Her Convention
description: The two-city rally, with Democrats celebrating at their convention in Chicago and an arena in Milwaukee, was a pointed rejoinder to Donald Trump and a significant flexing of the party’s muscle.
content: Democrats managed to be in two places at once on Tuesday night, holding a ceremonial roll-call vote at their Chicago convention to celebrate Vice President Kamala Harris as their party’s nominee, while she herself rallied supporters roughly 80 miles north in Milwaukee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Jennifer Lopez Files for Divorce From Ben Affleck
description: The A-list couple, who married in 2022, had attempted to rekindle their romance after close to two decades.
content: Jennifer Lopez filed for divorce from Ben Affleck on Tuesday after two years of marriage, capping a decades-long romantic history that spawned its own famous portmanteau: “Bennifer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Almeida and Jon Cherry
title: A 12-Minute Show, Played Only Once, Just Might Live Forever
description: Every summer, hundreds of college-age musicians spend countless hours — and their own money — pursuing a single goal: the drum corps world championship.
content: The 159 members of the Bluecoats Drum and Bugle Corps are on the field. Sixty-four of them are standing on a fire-engine-red platform that fills the space between the hash marks and the 40-yard lines. They are dressed in white jumpsuits adorned with red lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Young Chung
title: My Race Through the Mini Crossword Archive
description: In March, Young Chung set a formidable goal for herself: Solve 3,600 Minis before the puzzle’s 10th anniversary on Aug. 21.
content: My heart pounded as I took a deep breath, readied my keyboard and hovered my mouse over the Mini Crossword’s “Play” button. I clicked and started typing in the answers as fast as I could. Cap. Chino. Latke. Eight. Fro. My breath caught as I looked at my results.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Six Questions We Asked 65 Democratic Convention Attendees
description: What some of the most committed Democrats think about Kamala Harris, the future of the party and more.
content: What some of the most committed Democrats think about Kamala Harris, the future of the party and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Dear Ex’ and More
description: I cover news in China and Taiwan with a focus on the technology sector for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I cover news in China and Taiwan with a focus on the technology sector for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angad Singh and James Robinson
title: Why Kamala’s Mom Was More ‘Brat’ Than She Is
description: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.
content: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Throop and Alexandra Eaton
title: Pro-Palestinian Protesters March Outside Chicago’s Israeli Consulate
description: The police faced off with pro-Palestinian protesters outside the Israeli Consulate in Chicago.
content: The police faced off with pro-Palestinian protesters outside the Israeli Consulate in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Barack Obama Calls for Unity in Soaring D.N.C. Speech
description: Former President Barack Obama blamed politicians and social media algorithms for deepening social and political divisions among Americans.
content: Former President Barack Obama blamed politicians and social media algorithms for deepening social and political divisions among Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: D.N.C. Holds Enthusiastic Roll Call to Nominate Harris
description: Delegates from each state and territory cast votes to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris as the official standard-bearer of the Democratic Party.
content: Delegates from each state and territory cast votes to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris as the official standard-bearer of the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Harris Campaigns in Milwaukee During Day 2 of D.N.C.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz, rallied the crowds the critical battleground state of Wisconsin.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz, rallied the crowds the critical battleground state of Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Alexandra Eaton, Noah Throop and Mark Boyer
title: Gen-Z Delegates Push for Change at the D.N.C.
description: The Harris campaign has unlocked a wave of enthusiasm among young voters. But how do Democrats plan to fix the real-world problems impacting their lives? We spoke to four young delegates about the issues driving Gen-Z.
content: The Harris campaign has unlocked a wave of enthusiasm among young voters. But how do Democrats plan to fix the real-world problems impacting their lives? We spoke to four young delegates about the issues driving Gen-Z.
source.name: The New York Times
